data.body:
Looks like you do have to translate them yourself, yes.

Typically, this is done by building a matrix that translates the points onto the origin, then rotates them onto the xy plane (or xz, if you're using z[oops, I mean y]-up).  I usually do this by first picking a world axis vector (e.g. [0, 0, 1], [1, 0, 0], [0, 1, 0], etc).  The steps to build the matrix then are (apologies in advance if I remember any details wrong):
- Calculate group normal vector:
  - Calculate center of polygon (either mean/average, or minmax)
  - For each point: 
    - Calculate triangle formed by point and two of its neighbors
    -  Add to group normal
  - Normalize group normal
- Cross normal with world axis to get a rotation vector (don't forget to normalize afterwards!)
- Calculate rotation angle with something like 'Math.acos(normal.dot(worldaxis))';
- Create rotation matrix from crossed vector and angle, e.g. 
  `new THREE.Matrix4().makeRotationAxis(axis, angle) //this might be -angle`
- Create translation matrix from (negated) center: 
  `new Marix4().makeTranslation(center.negate());`
- Final matrix will be something like 
  `matrix.copy(rotationmat).multiply(translationmat) //we want the translation applied first, so rotation happens about center`
